The advent of and proliferation of "civilian oversight," of police brings about important questions on these entities. Here, I provide my experiences over the years of dealing with both police auditors and civilian oversight boards. Question: If training in use of force is so important for police (and it is), why are these entities allowed to exist with little to no training? Having an uneducated opinion about a use of force incident allows personal agendas and bias to insert themselves. Is this the goal for many of those involved? https://lnkd.in/gyeFf5zT

Vulnerable communities likewise now include our men and women in policing, who are viciously attacked every day. https://lnkd.in/e-cJ5RrX

In light of this, I urge the Ontario Association of Chiefs of Police (@OACPOfficial) to take a bold stand on addressing the mental health of their members. The time for action is now. While we commend the ongoing efforts, it is crucial to move beyond mere acknowledgments and take concrete steps to support the mental well-being of those who protect and serve our communities. Operational stress injuries, including post-traumatic stress and suicidal ideation, are real challenges that require more than lip service; they demand action, understanding, and comprehensive support systems. Let us not forget that behind every badge, there is a human being deserving of care, support, and understanding. As we celebrate the achievements of our newest members, let's also commit to ensuring their mental health and well-being are prioritized. The journey of a peacekeeper is both challenging and rewarding, and by fostering an environment that genuinely addresses mental health, we empower our officers to thrive, not just survive. #Badgeoflifecanada #HopeGrowthRecovery #Calltoaction #PAO
